DOC.TEXT: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve will move to push interest rates lower, possibly as early as this week, private economists say. The expected round of credit easing in response to evidence of a weakening economy and moderating inflation would cause a variety of business and consumer rates to fall, the economic forecasters say. Among the rates that could drop would be the prime rate and home mortgage rates. The Federal Open Market Committee is meeting today and Tuesday for its final strategy sessions of the year.

U.S. corporations are skimming billions of dollars from their employees' pension programs to finance buyouts, ward off takeovers or simply pocket the profits. These ``reversions,'' legal under a 1974 law, face growing criticism amid warnings that parts of the nation's $2 trillion private pension system are on shaky ground and could eventually force a massive taxpayer bailout.

The U.S. merchandise trade deficit surged to $10.2 billion in October, the worst imbalance in 10 months, as a record level of imports swamped a small rise in exports, the Commerce Department said. The October deficit was a sharp 19.8 percent higher than the September imbalance of $8.51 billion, reflecting a higher foreign oil bill and big increases in imports of food and industrial supplies, the government said Friday.

A sharp drop in gasoline costs helped push wholesale prices down in November for the third time in five months, the government reported. The annual rate of inflation, as measured by the Labor Department's Producer Price Index released Friday, was 4.6 percent for the first 11 months of the year, up from 4 percent for all of 1988 but much lower than was feared earlier this year. The index dipped 0.1 percent last month following a 0.4 percent gain in October and a 0.9 percent spurt in September. It declined 0.5 percent in July and 0.4 percent in August.

Industrial production was little changed in November despite rebounding from a major strike and a devastating earthquake, the government said. The Fed attributed the 0.1 percent gain Friday to a rebound from the Boeing Co. strike and from lingering effects in the computer and related industries from the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake in October, when output slumped 0.6 percent.

Eastman Kodak Co. said costs related to a restructuring announced this year would reduce fourth quarter earnings by $273 million, significantly more than the company had predicted. The $273 million charge Friday brings Kodak's total 1989 restructuring costs to $500 million, or $850 million before taxes, spokesman Henry Kaska said. The photography giant had charged $227 million against its second quarter earnings.

The average U.S. income rose slightly in 1988, but was far outpaced by Japan, the World Bank reported. The average per capita income in the United States last year was $19,780, compared with $18,580 in 1987. In Japan, the average income rose from $15,840 to $21,040, the World Bank said Friday. The Swiss continued to rank first in per capita income with a 1988 average of $27,260, up from $21,310 in 1987.

A regional real estate slump prompted Bank of New England Corp. to announce it will sharply boost reserves against bad loans and that it expects a substantial loss for the year. The bank also announced Friday it had reassigned a senior executive overseeing its real estate group, that it was considering the sale and merger of some operations and that it may rescind its common stock dividend declared Nov. 27.

Gillette Co., trying to rebuild profits hurt by recent takeover battles, has announced it will realign its operations and sell some of its European business, affecting about 750 workers in the process. Gillette said Friday it was creating a North Atlantic Shaving and Personal Care Group that would encompass its shaving products and toiletries segments.

Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street's most notorious felon, has been permanently released from a federal prison camp and will serve the rest of his sentence at a Brooklyn halfway house, authorities said. Boesky, 52, was granted the transfer to the halfway house about 10 days ago from the minimum-security Lompoc Federal Prison Camp in California, where he was imprisoned since March 1988, prison spokesman Gavin O'Connor said Friday.

A midsession selloff drove stock prices lower Friday amid worries about real-estate finance and the outlook for the economy in early 1990. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.08 to 2,739.55, reducing its gain for the week to 8.11 points. The dollar finished mostly lower in thin dealings. Bond prices were predominantly lower. Gold and energy prices rose dramatically after Panama's latest declaration of hostility against the United States; livestock and meat futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed.
